review_title: UPS is a great place to work depending on where you are in your life.
job_title: Sales Associate in San Jose, CA
pros: Great Benefits and a very ethical company.  A well respected company which promotes great work ethics that can be taken anywhere else if you so choose.  Plenty of opportunity for advancement and a great place to start a career.
cons:
Pay is sub standard but if you move up the politics and responsibility are not worth the extra pay so you end up decided to stay where you are at. Almost feel like you are at a dead end unless you want to bleed brown.
No chance of thinking outside the box. If you prove that a certain method works, you have no outlet to present it. 
Mentality of "you can disagree but you cant disobey"  Upper mgmt is very disconnected from the front lines.
Too much admin work and less time focusing on your real job. 
Constantly asked to fill out action plans or logs so that someone can justify their job. Again, you are removed from focusing on the real problems.

pros: I advise anyone to read my "cons" before reading Pros.  One of the great pros of UPS are the people.  I loved my direct supervisor and manager.  If more people of their stature populate middle and senior management, then employees are going to love the Company.
cons:
I want to preface this by saying as an adult, no matter how much effort I put in, there's always room for improvement.  I'm also a benevolent person.  So when this happened to me, I didn't know what to do.  Details follow below:

I was hired into Corporate as an analyst - and I'm very grateful UPS gave me the opportunity to build my future.  Few weeks in, at our 3rd or 4th team meeting, one of the managers told all Asians to go sit in a corner.  I was told he was joking and my supervisor advised me to report it to HR.  Because I was inexperienced (work & life), benevolent, and only two months with the company,  I didn't want to blemish a ten-year tenure.  Little did I know that there was a historical pattern of discrimination and racial insensitivity at the company.  Before I left, I found that the director (retiring) had a slew of racially-based complaints against him.  There was also a time in the past where UPS saw a trend of Asians leaving the company.  HR executives coined this phenomena as the "Asian Exodus".

The whole ordeal was very depressing to go through.  The team meeting shenanigans also embarrassed me in front of all my coworkers.  For those out there reading, I think the company has made changes, but I still wanted to share my experience.

review_title: Overview of part-time from a Part-time reloader
job_title: Re-Load Package Handler in Sylacauga, AL
pros: UPS offers part time employees quite possibly the best bennefits of any part time employer i have seen. Depending on location part time employees may also bennefit from tuition re-imbersment of (dont quote me) i believe around a cap of $2k per semester. Part time employees usually have shifts that are perfect for working around a full-time job. I know of a few peple at our center that own their own businesses that work part-time for the insurance. Pay is prety decent although of course for the work, I would enjoy a little more. Starting pay in my area is 9.00/hr with a yearly raise of 0.50. usually i see about a two year employment time before part time employees are able to bennefit from more opportunities such as: extended hours, cover driving, management, possibly even full time positions depending on just how lucky they are. Also on how they handle their job and how they perform under stress.
cons: The work is a little rough at times but for only a couple hours of your garunteed 3.5 hours. so it is manageable.

pros: The salary and benefits are great and the quarterly bonuses are more competitive than any other LTL carrier. You receive a new car every year and can use the company gas card for personal use! You are backed by a good brand and various counterparts from other UPS divisions that constantly provide you leads and basically schedule all your sales calls for you. The local offices are close knit and much like a family.
cons: Where to begin....you make good money but you will work very hard for it. On the freight side, you are more of a specialist making appearances on joint sales calls with you UPS package counterpart reps than your own rep. There are not enough freight reps!! I was 1 rep working with 13 package reps covering the same area and was constantly pulled around on calls with them and problem resolution. We all got along great but be prepared to be overwhelmed by them and feel like you are beneath them because you work for the freight division. You are hired as an LTL rep but be prepared to have a quota for all divisions including technology, international, ground, TL, volume etc. The companies service is not reliable and no money is put into this division. If UPS did invest time and money into this division it would be unstoppable but I didn't see this in the years I worked there. UPS corp. could care less about the freight division. Package is their bread and butter and they have this division to bundle and compete with FedEx.

job_title: Account Executive in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Job security
Known name in industry
cons: Please avoid working here at all costs. The company will do anything they can to not pay you for your hard work. UPS has the most complicated sales compensation plan and has even CHANGED their compensation plan AFTER a quarter has ended in order to not pay their people for the company's 2020 growth. It's disgusting and foul to change the rules of the game after the game has ended. They constantly make up excuses and hold back people from advancing. Do yourself a favor and when you interview ask how "How is the compensation plan work?" If you can't understand it with 2 sentences max or can repeat it clearly to someone in max 2 sentences than it's over complicated for a reason; to make sure their people understand as little as possible and find any reason to not pay you. Also, your ability in other areas does not matter, whatever department you are in, good luck trying to get into a different one. They will give you endless hoops of saying you need to do this or that or meet these people here and it will get you nowhere. Nepotism gets people moving up far and quick here, ability and true talent usually leave. And if you do move up, the best part; they tell you what your pay is ONLY AFTER you accept the position. How does that work in any other company? It doesn't. They believe titles matter more than compensation and have one of the lowest base and commission structures in regards to sales.

job_title: Operations Supervisor in Willow Grove, PA
pros:
Company will always be here. They run it very well (aside from a hiccup here and there...COUGHTNTCOUGH) Numerous employee discounts and benefits.  Full benefits for part-timers.  Once you make full time in mgmt the sky is the limit, and the pay is great. Part timers face fierce competition and politics.  Fortune 50 company (the top 50 of fortune 500). 
Any tier 1 company will have a discount for UPS employees. All the big wireless companies do for example.

You will never be wondering what your boss thinks of you. They will always be forthcoming about it.
cons:
Very physical and demanding job. If you aren't up to it you will be harassed to perform better until you do...or until you quit.  Some workers learn they have a "can't get fired" card from the union and slack off, which makes everyone else's job harder.
 A pat on the back happens far less often than a slap in the face (not literally) Operations people put up the best numbers ever and the performance based bonus checks (MGMT) and Christmas turkeys (Everyone) -- poof-- disappeared, and haven't been back in 4 years.

review_title: I very much enjoyed most people I worked with, I really enjoyed my job. I was let go because I couldn't lift 600 packages an hour that weighed 50+ mind you Im a 5'4 135 pound girl and they didn't have to let me go they had plenty of other open positions I could of excelled at, I had 3 people fighting to keep me there but my supervisor wouldn't allow me to be moved to another section and I've only spoken to him maybe twice. I worked there as a temp back in May and almost cried when I had to leave and everyone liked me so much they told me to reapply so I did and got a completely different job I was the only girl doing this job and I didn't mind but from what I've been told and what I seen I heard sexism is a big issue there. I drove from Philadelphia to willow grove 45 minutes every day at 3:30am never late and never missed a day and worked my hardest and the best I could but they still let me go and the teamsters union was supposed to look into it but never did. I was only part time, 4 hour days 5 days a week and for some reason they found it appropriate after I drove 45 minutes to get there to let me go after about 45 minutes of being there and I was getting 40 -50 dollar paychecks

review_title: DECEPTIVE hiring practices and treatment of employees as well as RETALIATORY mgmt behaviors in Windsor CT warehouse.
job_title: UPS Part Time Package Handler in Windsor, CT
pros: $14.00 per hour. Sounds good but for only 10 - 12 hours a week with union dues are taken out it's not worth it! You end up with about $125 per week. Your pay goes into the gas you spend driving to and from work. So for a back breaking job you end up with about $75 per week. Who can survive off of that.
cons: They advertised the position M-F 5:30 - 10:30 (eve). On the first day they gave orientation and said we can expect to receive 25+ hours. That was a lie. Since the day me and others started we've only been given 3 hours sometime 2.5 hours a day because there is not enough work. Each week my check has been about $125 when I was expecting $300 based on the hours we all applied for and on top of this little pay of $125 they deduct $25 for union fees. Each week mgmt promised the hours would pick up. I was considered a hard worker so they awarded me with a small gift my second week there. The next week I was told that they were promoting me to supervisor which would give me more hours and more money. Two days later they hired another supervisor with no explanation to me. The next day I called out and when I returned the following day the new supervisor set me up in my station and then the manager said "oh you called out yesterday, well we really dont need you today so you can leave". This is RETALIATION for me calling out one day. UPS I'm disappointed you allow managers to take advantage of those trying to get their feet on the ground and work hard for you. I guess Warehouse employees are meaningfulness. Turnover rate is high because of false advertising of hours. Why stay to risk our lives to COVID for 2 hours a day when we were sold on 25+ per week. BTW - there it's no AC to loaders. You work in a hot truck.

review_title: UPS - The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly
pros:
The sky is the limit. Tremendous amount of opportunity. Cutting edge technology. Ability to carve out a career with multiple facets within the same company is unheard of - at UPS you can do this. Training for FT supervisors is excellent if taken advantage of. 
Many excellent employees both hourly and management.
Very good Corporate Vision.
Very good Corporate Citizen.
cons:
UPS has a problem executing at all levels; Corporate ideals not played out on the local level at all times. Message given by Corporate is often contradicted by the time it reaches the district level. UPS operates much like a Federal and State system of governance. Each District is accountable to Corporate but has flexibility in how it accomplishes goals. 
Methods of accountability fosters and rewards "erronious reporting of numbers" and often mistakenly reinforces "the ends justifying the means."  This is not intentional but it is widespread. UPS is a company that focus is on numbers and loses sight of the larger picture at times.
UPS has a strong Union presence (Teamsters) and it does make the business struggle to maintain a profit and productivity. There is a "them versus me" mentality that doesn't work on either side of the fence.
UPS has a serious problem with how they treat all employees.
There is no such thing as "work life balance" at UPS. The hours are very demanding: scheduled 50/week with actual hours worked almost always 60-70+ depending upon your position. Expectation of 24/7 availability with holiday and weekend work expected also.
Wage and benefits plan no longer premier.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Bell, CA
pros: Weekly pay, Holidays off (paid holidays after one year), full time benefits for part time workers (after one year). Honestly, the UPS experience depends on what you make of it. You’re basically getting paid to work out (you will drop some pounds). If you enter with a negative attitude and mindset, that’s how your day is going to turn out. But if you walk in ready to put in work, then everything will be fine. The people are great but every job has those few people who get on your nerves. Free dress but keep it appropriate. Work out clothes. Steel toe non slip work boots. Recommend work gloves.
cons: 10 minute breaks after working 3 sometimes 3 1/2 hours. Working us like slaves. Takes a toll on the body. Wear a back brace, knee brace, and wrist brace because it will eventually hurt. Allowed to bring cellphone in after working for 70 days. Otherwise leave it in the car or locker. Bell Hub is an open building. Meaning it’s not closed in with walls. Depending on your area you can see the mountains. In the winter, wear layers. In the summer, a thin t-shirt and shorts will do. A tough job. Not for the weak. People quit everyday because they want you to move faster than you actually can. Fast paced. Heavy packages. Apply if you’re up for the challenge. Good luck.

pros:
- Excellent benefits! I have had Medical, dental, vision & life insurance for my entire family for almost 8 years. No premiums, low co-pays.
-  Pension (5 years Vested)
- Tuition Reimbursement
-  Paid vacation plus one full week of option days to use as you please.
-  Raises automatically 1-2 times per year depending on union contract agreement. 
-  Lots of opportunity to advance in to management you want to.
cons:
-  Hot In t be summer, cold in the winter. Dirty & loud.
-  Hard work. Hard on your knees and joints.
-  You have to start at the bottom either loading or unloading trucks for at least six months before you can try to bid out of the position.  It can take years to get out of those trucks due to a long seniority list.
-  Pushed hard by management to meet deadlines. 
-  It's necessary to work two jobs for many years, live with others to keep living expenses low to support yourself as a part time employee.
-  It takes many years working as a part-time employee to be able to obtain a full-time position. About seven  years for package car driver,  15-20 for full-time in the building,  20 for feeder driver.
-  Start times are different every day.
-  Very hard to get hours as a part-time employee which makes it difficult to survive without having another job.
-  Under the current contract employees have to be employed for one year before getting the insurance/benefits package. 
-  Lazy people get moved up who have more seniority than you making more money. Nothing is based on performance.

review_title: Disparity when it comes to Driver Service Providers
job_title: Driver Service Provider in Fishersville, VA
pros: Great union support if you manage to qualify; excellent benefits for self and family; max out pay in 4 years
cons: After graduating from UPS Integrad School, the training you get at the center you work in is horrible.  You ride along with your trainer on day 1; you drive half the day on day 2; you drive the entire day by yourself with your trainer with you on day 3; you are sent out on your own by day 4 to sink or swim. You get an assigned route, but you are responsible for learning the area yourself, and the stops vary day to day. They do very little to ease you into the role, and will disqualify you at any time if they deem you "can't cut it". The guy on my route was shocked at the loads I got on my first day driving, saying not even seasoned drivers get this. Plus there is favoritism on who they work with and try to keep on versus not. Can't ever really prove racial bias, but center is very non-diverse, with the only minorities there having been with the company 10+ years, longer than the entire management staff currently there.  I'm real curious to see what data they have to show just cause for some of their firing if you compare routes, package loads, and timeframe to complete deliveries between other trainees.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Parsippany, NJ
pros:
Great benefits, fast paced environment. It's a simple job and easy to do if you can find the energy for it. If you can get your sleep cycle and professional life to sync up with the hours (4am-9am), it's a quick couple of bucks.

There are supervisors who will train you and help you load faster and better. Assuming you get hooked up with one of the few good supervisors that is.
cons: Upper management was prone to fits of shouting, the one of the supervisors in particular would berate and belittle employees, which set an example for some of the part time supervisors. Made it an unhealthy, and tense work environment. review_title: Great if youre a Teamster and keep track of your hours
job_title: Night Shift Package Handler in Harrisburg, PA
pros: The benefits, if you can make it through the probationary period and become a teamster you will reap the benefits the Union provides (401k and Medical)
cons: You are treated like a machine, management doesn't care about your safety or well being. It definitely is a numbers game and all they want is for you to load their trucks (if you're a package handler) all night long. Drop below what they expect of you for packages per hour and your manager will be paying you a visit. They also don't follow their own safety rules, for example: You are never to lift any package over 80 lbs by yourself, but on the job if you ask for help and no one comes over to help then managers force you to do it alone, they dont care if you get injured. their equipment is also unsafe, you are supposed to report damaged equipment to management and they are required to replace or repair it but this never happens. And If you are unlucky enough to get hurt on the job be ready to have management looking at you like a hawk as if you did it on purpose! Also you have to make sure you get paid for your hours, if you dont keep track of hours worked then UPS will pay you for less time and essentially get some work from you for free.

review_title: Not the best job on earth but not the worst.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Hodgkins, IL
pros:
The whole UPS community can agree that insurance benefits are (were) some of the best any worker could ever wish for.  I wouldn't know about them personally as I have not been there for long enough.  
Then there's tuition assistance at $15,000 and at least $1 raise per year.  
The work is challenging yet can be fun, a lot of the people who work for this company are amazing and there is never any worry about having to work weekends or holidays.
cons:
Knowing that you're working for one of the largest companies in the world, and while they continue to generate record profits in the billions: they'll occasionally request concessions on benefits and things of that nature.  
The supervisors are usually rushy, unsatisfactory work ethic is practiced regularly to meet deadlines and the amount of money you are looking at from the end of the week is not always pleasant.  Especially if you do not have a second job or have not been there for at least 10 years. 
The starting rate of pay is abysmal, being promoted is very highly unlikely (unless we're talking about P/T supervisory positions) and because of all these things one must deal with on a regular basis: lots of people do not stay for any longer than 3 months.

review_title: Best job you can get without a college degree.
pros:
By far the best benefits you can get for only working 17 hours a week. 

Job advancement all depends on timing (everything is seniority based except management) but is very much worth it if you can become a package/feeder/air/combo driver.
 
Great work out.  

Teamster (union) influence (in most areas it's pretty good - some centers I've worked at were absolutely terrible as far as the company/union relations)
cons:
Very physical - at my current center (of 5 years) I've seen 4 or 5 military reserve employees quit due to physical stress (they actually walked out mid sort). When working a night sort (local sort), summer temperatures in the trailers average over 140 degrees. During the winter, preload sorts (morning sorts) can be single digit temperatures depending on where you live - and you WILL work in it.  

Though I listed it as a pro, seniority based job advancement can be terrible in specific cases. 

You can only transfer as a part-timer by means of education, death in the family, or mortal health/sickness. Transferring is impossible if there aren't any openings.

review_title: UPS has unrealistic expectations of its people and how what they expect them to do
pros: It is easy to get a job there and the starting pay is decent. There is room for advancement if you are in school or want to become a driver. They reimburse some school tuition and if you can stick it out for a year you get full health benefits for free.
cons: You have to start out as part time only and there are no 9am to 5pm jobs. They try to work with as minimal a staff as possible so either they will try to send you home as soon as you come in or you will do the work of the other 3 people they sent home. They are union so there are a lot of people who will do as little as possible and you get to pick up the slack because they are union and very difficult to fire. They promote people to supervisor with no qualifications and no ability and expect other people with no ability to train them. You get yelled at and you work your butt off and get no recognition for it. Oh and last but most important the time clock does not work in your favor so unless you monitor you time closely you will be working for free.

pros: Just about the only thing worth working for UPS as a package handler was the benefits. they have one of the best benefits packages in all the jobs I've had.
cons: The pay is very low for the amount of PHYSICAL work that is required of you. On a weekly average, I only took home $160. I understand it's a part-time position however for this amount of money for this kind of work you're better off choosing another job. The job is physically straining and the company's logistics doesn't have a proper system to make sure that all employees are given the same amount of work. If you are an exceptionally fast worker they will shuffle you to unload another trailer of another employee. Mind you, you're still getting the same pay even though your coworker is not working with the same effort. I always pay attention to companies that have a fast turnover of employees and UPS is one of those billion dollar companies that don't compensate their employees well enough and that's why people don't enjoy working here.

pros: Great pay, the driver for the most part are very chill and are more dependable than HR for informations.
cons: HR is crap and so are the so called, "coordinators" which are also seasonal workers. Both are useless and can't give any useful informations. Okay, i understand that the coordinator can't, but so are the HR. Also, don't trust the so-called they can pick you up thing, cause they won't! And if you work over 8 hours UPS will take one hour from you every day. Apparently, there is a law in the U.S or whatever, where they have to provide you at least one hour of lunch break if you work over 8 hours. Which, just saying you will work over 8 hours everyday basically other than a Saturday. I didn't know that until my driver told me on my on my mid second week. So, remember to take your lunch everyday or you will lose one hour of pay EVERYDAY! Terrible company/management for that part cause they don't tell you crap and on top of that they are stealing your hard earn money. Just to protect themselves from breaking the law and yet doing this in my opinion, is no different because there were no prior warning to this.

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Louisville, KY
pros: I work for UPS in Louisville Ky at their main sorting center. The facilities are impressive and certain parts of it are state of the art. Employees who work the night shift have the opportunity to have their college tuition paid for if they attend the University of Louisville. I did this and received my Bachelor's degree and graduated debt free.
cons: UPS is a greedy company. The starting pay is $10 an hour for union employees with yearly raises. All employees start out as part time and it can take up to 15 years before you will be offered a full time job. This goes for both union and supervisors. When I left I was a supervisor and made about $15 an hour part time. Most of my employees made more than me. Due to their low pay, many people in the area work for other companies doing similar jobs for better pay which leaves UPS understaffed for most of the year. Because of this, supervisors are expected to fill in for the lack in staffing even though it is against union regulations. Upper management seems oblivious to the bad conditions and does little to address it. I felt very under appreciated throughout my time at UPS. The union does not help the good employees, all they really do is prevent employees with poor attendance records from losing their jobs. If you are in school and want free tuition, than this is a good job for you, if you are not in school I would advise you to look elsewhere for a job.

review_title: Great, until I got into management
pros:
Great Pay
Great Benefits
Paid Vacations

As an hourly I was making $12 an hour with full benefits and 3 weeks of paid vacation. As a Supervisor I was making $15 an hour with 3 weeks of paid vacation, and only had to pay a small amount for benefits.
cons:
Treated poorly
Only one shift
Dirty

If you talk to a loader/unloader they will try and tell you how badly they have it because management treats them poorly. Its mostly a lie. I was a loader/pick off for 4 years before I went into management, and I was treated far worse as a supervisor then an hourly. a lot of the supervisors just suck it up and take it without saying anything, but it was pretty bad. 

You work the same shift everyday, so don't come into work one day asking if you can work a different shift next week then go back the week after that.

I have worked in 2 different UPS warehouses, and both were caked in dust. No lie I can breathe a lot better now that I don't walk into a dust box everyday. I think the Orlando hub opened in 1983, and it looks like it hasn't been cleaned since 1983. Be prepared to come home, blow your nose and have dust come out.

review_title: UPS the great skewer of statistics
job_title: Technical Support Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
Its a Job,
Pay is liveable.
40 hours a week
cons:
Its a technical call center run by non technical management for the most part.
Supervisors and Coaches are also non technical for the most part.
Unneccesary drama almost daily.
Skill or the ability to do the job is not required, just someone that comes to work everyday and will talk to management will get you promoted.
Technical Agents get no training whatsoever, sit down maybe listen to someone for 2 hours then start taking calls.
Management wants you to stay away from ACW Aux (After Call Work) and does not give Cart Blanche access to use the Supervisor directed Aux to help these new agents out. So we have to use ACW to help these agents on their calls to help internal UPS people mostly at package centers out and doing that in the end has an effect on your yearly raise, This is just one example, its an avalanche effect with no thanks for jobs well done only negative consequences.
There are many technical employee's with no technical skill's or employee's that follow the guidelines so closely they SEVERLY limit the ability to help our internal customers, these agents don't have the ability to think outside the box.
A simple unplanned listening to some of these agents would show UPS this problem, The problem with that is the Management, Supervisor's and coaches are very non technical, neither is our QA monitoring group.

review_title: Working for UPS is not what it seems
pros: ability to move up from hourly to part time supervisor, pay is about $19.80/hour. Limited to 27.5 hours/week outside of peak.
cons: Beyond part time supervisor, moving up is relatively hard. Transferring hubs is even harder if not nonexistent. Departments would rather let really good PT sups go work for other companies than open up a desperately needed FT spot (happened with 4 people in my department in less than about 9 months being there.  Hourly employees can make more than part time supervisors that are directly in charge of them. As a PT Sup you're basically responsible for everything, without FT pay (~$75k/year). Upper management just walks around asking for numbers nearly 90% of the shift. Expect to be thrown into massive peak season, untrained as hell. Union drivers are a nightmare and are pre-Madonnas to deal with.  Peak season is where the bread is made, all rules go out the window there expect 10-14 hour shifts daily from October-Feb. Massive turnover in hourly and PT Sups. Conditions at the PHXAZ hub are horrendous. Go to Goodyear if available.

-  During peak season (Thanksgiving and Christmas), the shifts start about 12 am 
    to 1 am and end at 8-9 am.
-   Management is supportive and knows how physically demanding the job is. The
    expectation is that you will be a good pre-loader within 1-2 months.
-   Fellow pre-loaders are supportive and will teach you what helps them, 
     especially when you asked them.
-  Offers to help with college tuition.
-  Ability to grow within the company.
cons:
-  This is labor-intensive, meaning you should expect to be tired at the end of your
    shift. Your hands, arms, shoulders will get a workout and will feel sore.
-  This is not a glamour job. Nobody cares how you look. Just work hard.
-  You will get frustrated by the number of large packages and how will all the 
    packages fit onto the trucks but it will workout. Your supervisor will help you.
-  Seniority rules so no matter how good or hard you work, you will get cut and 
    sent home early. They do guarantee a 3 hour shift. 
-  This truly is a part time job. This will not sustain you.

review_title: Great pay and benefits, but the culture is lousy
pros: Pay is fantastic, especially for someone without a college degree. For drivers, getting out and about all day, meeting new people, and getting smiles from so many people during the day is incredibly satisfying. Decent retirement, available 401(k), stock plan for eligible employees, decent vacation time.
cons:
Incredible amount of ever-present pressure to perform.
Performance goals are constantly ratcheted up.
Complete negativity with the "manage by exception" management philosophy.
Continual parade of blustery management types through the revolving door, each of which intends to leave his/her mark by changing something.
Every new program, piece of equipment, operational change, or policy is designed with one thing in mind..... Getting more stops out of the drivers. The management who read this will say "Well....DUH!", without even thinking that there are limits to human performance.
The systemic rot within corporate management is likely the worst part. There are still good supervisors left in the company, but human decency is not a valued trait in upper management, so the lower level supervisors that display compassion, or a willingness to do what is right by the humans they supervise, are locked into lower management. Machine like devotion to efficiency and performance are the most valued properties in upward bound managerial employees.

review_title: I love the fact that at UPS we get the job done every time...that's what we do best!
pros: The people I work with are wonderful!  There is a real sense of family and this made going to work fun!
cons: A lot of time is spent away from home!  You are required to be working almost all day!  If you go in early thinking you can call it a day early, you're mistaken!  You need to plan to be there for the duration!  There are too many bosses giving orders!  The communication is really poor from the Division levels down to the hourly employees.!  The work demand is extremely high and you had better work round-the-clock to complete your tasks or you'll work even longer hours because you will be working on Action Plans!  There are many responsibilities and you need to be thick-skinned or you won't make it in the UPS family!

job_title: Part Time Package Handler (Loader) in Fort Worth, TX
pros: UPS has a very strong union and as long as you don't move in to management, you will work under their protection. This can be extremely helpful in cases where they somehow skip your paycheck (which they will).
cons: You will not be rewarded for hard work. The harder you work, the harder they will push you. You are not allowed any days off (vacation or sick) for your first year of employment. When I was hired I made it very clear I would be gone for a week and was told that would be okay. When I returned and didn't receive my paycheck, I found out I was terminated without anyone telling me or my supervisors, so I technically worked a week without even being in their system. My supervisors got me back in the system but I didn't receive the paycheck for that week of work for another three weeks. Pay rates are flat throughout the building so if you are a loader, you'll get paid the same amount as people doing less than half of the amount of work. Supervisors are power hungry and will not treat you as human beings. In the few months I worked at UPS, I saw a total of 4 paychecks go unpaid. Moving into other jobs within the building is completely seniority based. It doesn't matter how good a worker you are, all they care about is how long you've been there.

job_title: Business Development Representative in Nottingham, England
pros:
Excellent pay. 
Pension.
Pay rise every year.
Good stability.
Good holiday entitlement that rises with longer service.
Lovely colleagues to work with.
cons:
Management are complete bullies.
The pressure put on employees to achieve unrealistic targets is horrible and employees are treated as just a number.
The money is very good but the stress isn’t healthy and if in that environment long enough you will crack.
They micromanage departments and performance is all stat based - it’s all about productivity and what is calculated possible on a spreadsheet with no regard for employees working environment , mental state or personal circumstances. 
Even when achieving targets the bar is raised higher and higher with no thanks but the minute targets aren’t hit you are taken in the office to be reviewed and asked the exact reason why.
Sick pay is at management discretion so if you are unfortunate to have a manager that you don’t get on with, this will be difficult.
HR make up their own rules as they go along but can get away with it because it is a huge corporate company. 
If you want kids they make it very difficult and aren’t very flexible- I’ve witnessed managers making sarcastic comments to employees about their choices to have children and it not fitting with ups vision. 
There are a lot of long standing employees and I can see why due to pay but it’s almost an institution and only after leaving a company like that (after a decade of service) do you realise just how strict and unpleasant the working environment actually is.
